content.user_title: Analyze genomic data with pysam toolkit
content.value_statement: Bioinformatics researchers need efficient tools to process large genomic datasets. Pysam provides a Pythonic interface to htslib for reading, writing, and analyzing SAM/BAM/CRAM alignments, VCF/BCF variants, and FASTA/FASTQ sequences.
actual_capabilities: Process VCF/BCF variant files with genotype data
Extract sequences from indexed FASTA files
Calculate coverage statistics and pileup analysis
limitations: Requires indexed files for random access operations
Limited to genomic file formats supported by htslib
Large files may require significant memory

use_cases.title: Analyze sequencing coverage
use_cases.description: Calculate per-base coverage from BAM files to identify low coverage regions in exome sequencing data

use_cases.title: Filter variants by quality

use_cases.title: Extract gene sequences
use_cases.description: Extract promoter and coding sequences from reference genome for downstream analysis

best_practices: Always create index files before random access operations
Use context managers or explicitly close files to free resources
Process regions in parallel for independent genomic analyses
anti_patterns: Don't iterate entire files when indexed fetch is possible
Avoid loading entire VCF files into memory for large datasets
Never ignore coordinate system differences (0-based vs 1-based)

faq.question: Why do I need index files?
faq.answer: Index files (.bai, .crai, .fai, .tbi) enable random access to specific genomic regions without reading the entire file

faq.question: What's the difference between 0-based and 1-based coordinates?
faq.answer: Pysam uses 0-based coordinates (Python convention) but VCF files and region strings use 1-based coordinates

faq.question: How do I handle large BAM files efficiently?
faq.answer: Use fetch() with specific regions, enable multiple_iterators if needed, and process in parallel for independent regions

faq.question: Can I modify BAM records in place?
faq.answer: Yes, but create a copy first. Some attributes like query_qualities require special handling after sequence changes

faq.question: What's the difference between fetch() and pileup()?
faq.answer: fetch() returns reads overlapping a region, while pileup() provides base-by-base coverage across the region

faq.question: How do I extract sequences around variants?
faq.answer: Use VariantFile to get variant positions, then FastaFile.fetch() with position +/- flanking region size
